posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26207157
Because Audi likes to make modular engines, so if you use the same 82.5x92.8mm bore and stroke in every engine and simply change cylinder count you can get any sort of displacement you need. For example, all of the following engines are related:
-The 1.8/2.0 L4
-The 2.2 L5
-The 2.7/2.8 V6
-The 3.6/4.2 V8
And then around the 2000s Audi started using a new bit of engines that were all shared engineering
-The 2.5 L5
-The 3.0/3.2 V6
-The 4.2 V8
-The 5.0/5.2 V10
The 07K engine was according to VW based on the Gallardo V10. Unlike most inline engines from VW which used an 88mm bore spacing at the time, the 07K used a 90mm bore spacing like VW V engines. Furthermore the 07K uses a similar timing drive and cylinder head, and the V10 uses the parts prefix 07L. Naturally aspirated 07Ks actually have the heads cast to support VVT on the exhaust and direct injection but aren't finished to allow this.

>tl;dr:
The 5 cylinder is half of a gallardo engine which was cheap to make.

>>26207642
According to Audi the main reason was because they wanted to keep their cylinder bores consistent, so they couldn't make a bigger 4 cylinder for fear of making the stroke too long, so they slapped another cylinder on instead. A straight 6 cylinder wouldn't fit in the front of an Audi due to their layout ahead of the axle. When they developed their V6 they had a better option than a 5 which is why they phased them out. iirc the RS3 5 is based off the EA888 while the 2.5 in the Golf/Jetta is from the V10 as above poster stated because it has rear timing chains where the RS3 doesn't.

>>26207855
Mostly true except the RS3 engine is truely based on the Golf/Jetta/Passat/Rabbit 2.5 except the head machining is complete and the additional boss on the block for the HPFP (there is an idler gear on the port injected 2.5 instead of the hump and eccentric on the DI engine). There are other differences like the RS3 engine has an 8 bolt flywheel flange vs the 6 bolt or the fact the head integrates the girdle + valve cover into one or the ttrs/rs3 engine coming in either aluminum or CGI flavors for the block vs regular cast iron on the N/A engine.

posts.name: PackardAnon

>>26189116
Man do I love wiring on old cars. I've been going through the diagram for the Packard; the car is like, 70 wires max. $100 of wire and crimps, and a fuse block gets me a brand new harness.

In other news, I've been diagnosing the overdrive on the car. It's got an R9 unit; it's pretty simple, but it has its quirks. It's got this kickdown switch which grounds the distributor, and that wire is cut (gee, I wonder why lol). The primary Energizer is a centrifugal governor that I'm pretty sure is burned up, and it goes into a dual-coil relay that controls a solenoid with two windings (pull-in, and hold-in). I checked the solenoid, I know it's good; I'm gonna test the relay to make sure it works, jumper past the governor (which is on the ground side funnily enough), and see if I don't get a click. Wish me luck!

Well, that's just it. And I honestly appreciate the sentiment. I don't need to spend a whole lot of money at all, and I'm still gonna have to learn how to do all these things. Two cars are projected to make it out of this, but I don't know which ones will yet.

900 for two chassis + 1 engine/trans.
740 for a wagon in another state - missing windows and front bumper. Will have to spend 1.7 to bring her down later.
200 for a UHaul trailer for a day.

I haven't had to spend a whole lot of money on tools and resources is which is amazing, and most of the important parts of the cars are complete and intact. The main issue is the body work, and in order to actually learn the craft, I have to work at it and work at it a LOT. I need to learn how to deal with rust, learn how to weld, and fresh sheet metal is honestly around $20 per square yard, and on top of that, I'm setting up an electrolysis tank in a week.

Engine hoist and balancer will be bought relatively soon as well. It may not seem like it, but I honestly feel like I'm in a pretty good spot right now when I consider everything.

>>26205268
- Calipers and brakes need to be cleaned and appear to be in decent condition. Would need a full disassembly for diagnostic.
- Drums need to be cleaned and double-checked, because I'm not entirely sure. Shoes somewhat corroded on the rear.
- Brake lines need to be reattached with a fluid flush.
- Shocks struts and springs are in good condition for daily, but not for racing.
- Universal wiring kit - 550
- Fuel lines, hoses - I'm not sure how much I need yet, but probably would be around 150
- Gaskets and O-Rings would be cheap by themselves but definitely add up over time.

The brakes would be an issue if I have trouble cleaning them, but I won't know until I take them all off and dunk them into an electrolysis tank.
Half the exhaust line would need to be replaced. I just don't want to fuck up the orange wagon when I get it and I'm glad I have an option to actually experiment here, and learn from my mistakes with a crash course with few consequences and potentially a pretty nice payoff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26206273
I can tell you that if you're doing this right you need
Shoes and pads
Hardware kits
Almost definitely new calipers and cylinders or seal kits for them if they're shitty old cars that have been sitting
Rubber brake lines
Fluid to flush and fill the system
Tires
Plugs, wires, cap and rotor
Valve cover gaskets are probably old and leaky
Radiator and heater core hoses
Antifreeze for the cooling system
Probably a new radiator cap
I'd do the thermostat since you're in there
If it's a manual you probably want to do the clutch unless it looks really good
Fluid for the transmission
Fluid and rtv or a seal for the differential
Axle seals might need to be done if they're leaking
Does the engine or transmission have rubber mounts? The old rubber is probably cracked and shot
Does it rain where you live? 50 year old door seals don't hold up well
Gas tank is probably going to need to be cleaned, might have to replace the sending unit if it's all rusted up
Carb is definitely going to need a gasket kit and cleaning at a minimum, plus a new air cleaner
Engine needs fresh oil and a filter
Then there's gonna be weird little nickel and dime shit you don't even think about, connectors for wiring fixes and other stuff. It's going to add up fast. I'm not telling you not to do it but you have to understand what it's going to entail.

On the scooter pictured(L O N D O N) it cannot, as there is no hub motor or any other kind of connection to another motor on the front wheel.
Regenerative braking works by using the motor as a generator thus providing a resistance to rotation.
That, i repeat, cannot happen here, as no motor is connected to the front wheel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26207959
Having driven both a Mercedes like this, and a Tesla I have to say that I like Tesla's implementation better.

Tesla does stuff that makes the screen not annoying like knowing when sunset is every day and automatically switching to night mode which lowers the brightness, goes to dark mode styling, and minimizes the blue on the screen so you're not bleaching your eyes.
Mercedes meanwhile has settings that let you change every little thing about the dashboard displays and the interior accent lighting, but it seems to just keep the same color settings all the time.

If Tesla is Gnome, Mercedes seems to be going the KDE approach. The Merc feels more gimmicky, like they're just throwing in all the bells and whistles they can without thinking about the whole. The Tesla interface by contrast feels better thought out even if its not as configurable.
Its honestly not what I was expecting at all. I had the idea of Merc as a more refined and aristocratic brand.

Not to say Tesla's implementation is perfect, honestly it was better a year or two ago and has gotten worse because they seem to have employed UI designers who weirdly aren't thinking about the fact its a car and the driver is going to need to control things without taking their eyes off the road. Things that used to work as imprecise gestures now require precise taps.
Car makers should really take a look at Valve's Steam Input and take a page from that. Give the driver some additional controls they can configure as they see fit or use as modifiers.

>They just keep dying because they're no where near as efficient as normal cars
LOL no. The older generation EVs died out because with lead acid batteries they could get maybe the stored energy of maybe 1/2 of one gallon of gas.
They were really efficient at low speeds which let them compete with horses, but early gas cars could burn through fuel like crazy and still have more range at higher speeds.
Initially this made gas cars basically only a toy for the extremely wealthy, but fuel subsidies post WW1 brought the price of fuel down, and more reliable engines and electric starters allowed gas cars to go mainstream.
Something the early car enthusiasts absolutely hated, but its what led to the status quo we have today where Karen drives around in a 1700 Wh/mi SUV and doesn't see anything wrong with that.

>We're in like a 5th "EV revolution" and your $150k Tesla
A new $25k electric car today has the equivalent of 2 gallons of gas. More than the stored energy in the early $80k+ cars Tesla made. That's why modern EVs aren't like the EVs of the past.

>half the range of a 1999 Crown Vic
A Crown Vic does about 16mpg (2100 Wh/mi), it can only drive about 300 miles on a tank of gas because it has a 19 gallon (640kWh) fuel tank.
For comparison a similarly sized, and much more powerful electric full size sedan today can go 500 miles on a bit over 100kWh.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26203299
>10 minute recharge it would be a game changer
Typical fast charging sessions at 250kW stations are already under 10 minutes for 15-20kWh. Sure its not a 'full charge', but nobody uses fast chargers that way because the electricity from them is expensive and electricity at home is cheap. So people just top up enough to get where they're going. This is why EV sales have seen significant increases wherever 250kW fast charging has rolled out.
The older generation 150kW stations are still pretty good, but they typically take 15-20 minutes to add a decent amount of range.

Battery architectures allowing for faster charging speeds like 350kW are already in production, and battery architectures that can handle 750 or 1000kW are coming.
A 750kW charging capable car will be able to add 100 miles of range in about 2 minutes. About as fast as a gas car can add range.

>If we had a breakthrough battery improvement that allowed for 1000 mile range
Not quite 1000, but last winter a new battery got shown off that had 200kWh, or enough for about 800 miles of range. So far the reality of the EV market is nobody wants to pay for that kind of range, or they're putting these larger batteries into less efficient vehicles. So we see cars with 300, 400, or 500 miles and people just combine a meal stop with a fast charging session on longer trips.
Most people will probably take at least one half hour or longer break during a full day of driving, if there's a 50kW charger there, that eliminates the 'gas station' style 5-10 minute stop.

>it's mostly just a meme for rich people to virtue signal.
Most EVs sold today are under $50k, and the vast majority are under $75k. I know /o/ skews poor, but you don't have to be 'rich' to own one.
Most people buying EVs today want cars that are cheap to drive for commuting, or are car enthusiasts wanting to try out the new thing.
Environmentalists who want to advertise their beliefs are a pretty small percentage.

>>26203395
Gas cars need a lot of range, and the ability to refuel in about 5 minutes because filling them up is a pain.
The only time EVs need long range is the few days a year when they're driven a very long distance.

With my old Golf I put gas in about twice a month at a fuel station about 15 minutes away from my house. Now with my EV I can top up at home to be ready for any day of driving, and my most typical fast charging session is 5-10 minutes at a station about 100 miles away when I'm on my way home.
The daily driving experience is better, the experience on trips is a little worse, but mainly because charging is still not as common as gas stations.

When we get next-generation solid state 500 Wh/kg batteries with 1000kW fast charging, I'd honestly take a car with a lighter weight 300 or 400 mile range battery over a car with a 1000 mile battery.
The only place I see those really high capacity 200 or 300kWh battery packs making sense is trucks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26205262
>another accident like Fukushima will happen
Fukushima was an old reactor design, and they ignored important safety concerns. Japan won't make that mistake again. They will make clean modern nuclear power work, and other regions concerned about climate change will take note and buy modern safe 4th gen reactors from Japanese companies.

>electric cars to be powered by coal burning
Here's the thing, EVs don't have to be that efficient to come out ahead of gas cars even charging on 100% coal, around 3 miles a kWh. Plus no country, not even China, are 100% coal anymore.
The cleaner the grid gets the cleaner EVs get, and individuals can always invest in making their EVs cleaner, buying more efficient cars or home solar.

>The real downside is the long charging time
Most cars sit idle more than 90% of the time. The only issue with EVs is the current lack of charging infrastructure.

>the high energy that fast chargers demand.
The typical fast charging session adds about 15 to 25kWh, compare to a typical gas station stop that adds 200 to 300kWh. Not a big deal for gas stations because they have a big tank filled with fuel. Fast chargers paired with storage batteries, either co-located or attached to the same grid can provide the same fix. Much the same way that EVs L2 charge when power is cheap, storage batteries paired with fast chargers can buy electricity when its cheapest and deliver it on demand.
Plus no waiting for a truck when the tank runs dry.

>solid state batteries, which is far away from mass production.
Solid state batteries are already in mass production. The issue with them today and why they aren't being produced at GWh scales, is that they aren't better today than the best NMC cells, and they're more expensive than LFP or sodium ion cells.
Toyota says they're about 2 years away from bringing the price down and pushing ahead of NMC cells, and other companies are talking about similar time frames.

>cheaper running costs, directly a result of government subsidies.
LOL no. EVs pay much higher road use fees than gas cars, and the cost of electricity going into EVs can go up to as much as $15 a gallon equivalent before costing more than heavily subsidized gas per mile.
The only thing that makes EVs cheap to drive, and the reason why they're taking over despite laws that greatly favor internal combustion is that they're so incredibly efficient.

The typical ICE car in 2022 is still only around 25mpg, about where gas cars have been for decades, but EVs have gone from 100mpge ten years ago, to around 135mpge today, and getting 170mpge or more isn't uncommon.

>may be subjectively worse or better depending on the person.
The same can be said of internal combustion. Its great if money is no object for you in daily driving, you live right next to a gas station, and you routinely drive 800+ miles in a day non-stop, but most people are driving less than 50 miles a day and don't often drive more than 400 miles in a day where they spend a significant amount of time stopped at a destination. Affordable mid-range BEVs and PHEVs handle that normal driving pattern with no problems at a lower cost. Which is another reason they're catching on, especially among home owners.

>Maybe if batteries could..
All of those only apply to some batteries, or some electric cars.
Phantom drain can be solved just by using more efficient electronics, or including a small solar cell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Having emergency blankets is a thing for many issues.

A detail that people miss is that blankets get wet in a fog-window moist cabin. You need airflow. Cars are not made for insulation to live inside. So if a seat folds to expose the trunk you can hunker in there with a window open and whatever you can insulate the trunk with on the door side.

Extreme conditions means the window can be covered with snow. Set alarms to clear it. A long stick to wiggle to break the snow away without getting out of the warm spot is best.

A vehicles exhaust can make it to your window if the back of it is covered up. You can die from this. It will travel under the vehicle where the air pocket is and seep up into the doors/window you have open. Do not believe it cannot be blocked, it can be blocked ENOUGH to do damage to you.

If you have a river vehicle with a top exhaust vent and you think you're safe, you're not very safe from it either. Like I said, the water can enter and flood the fucker from above and I do mean condensation over hours of being wet. It comes out to gallons after 10 hours.
>it has to be MADE FOR WINTER STORMS not just river crossings

>reliability overblown
Anything can be overblown on the internet, but these do stand head and shoulders above their contemporaries. It's the build quality that is the real virtue though.
Shut the door of one, listen and feel it, and get back to me. For that matter, use the hazard lights switch of an early one as well. Oh, and check out the wear profile of MB-tex w123 seats at 300k miles. Oh and try to find a w123 whose factory rustproofing under the floorpans wore through (they will only rust from water pooling above; inside the car). It is true that these cars will die eventually if totally neglected, but there are stories of them running with a knock so bad it eats an entire piston until there is just a gnarled conrod left, and still going. It is true that some modern cars can pretty easily make 300k, maybe even some current German cars, but nothing at the price point of an E-class is built overall to the level of craftsmanship today that these were back then. And when parts do fail, the parts themselves are usually able to be disassembled and repaired e.g. replacing o-rings in the self leveling suspension valve, or replacing a simple check valve in the vacuum pump. Granted, they were also ~$32k in the early 1980s but much of that is due to crazy exchange rates with the deutschmark.

Picrel: the turbo compressor wheel of my previously neglected car at 330k miles when I got it; no intercooler to catch that debris that obviously left, but all cylinders still had compression within 5% of factory acceptable tolerance. Ran totally fine just didnt make any boost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For completeness I will post common w123 issues:
-Valve lash adjustment every 11k miles
-Fuel filters need changing, including the filter screen in the 40 year old rusty gas tank that is a bit of a mess and pain to access.
-Vacuum pump needs to work to turn off the car with the key, may need rebuild (replacements are NLA)
-turbos don't last, and are NLA. Good luck finding one NOS for under $1,000
-Injection pumps wear out with low sulfur fuel and are more mechanically complex than the rest of the engine. Can be rebuilt for now, parts supply is running low.
-wagon hydraulic rear self levelling suspension is robust, but nobody ever changes the fluid so it may be a corroded mess, hydraulic shocks are close to $1000
-injectors last 200k miles, with a poor spray pattern they can wear out the prechambers (NLA) and wash the oil film off the cylinders by spraying direct into the bores. This and low oil are the two surefire ways to kill an OM617. Injector rebuild costs ~$500 or more, done by some guy you find on a forum.
-alternator mounted voltage regulator fails. However, the alternator is beefy as fuck and has two belts for redundancy which is awesome. Retards bend/mutilate the alt adjustment bolt, which can make changing the alternator a royal pain.
-leaks. Holy shit you will stain every driveway or road you park on. Learn to park on gravel dirt or grass. The rms is a rope seal, requires engine or transmission removal. They also leak from the connection between the oil filter housing and block; gasket was the wrong material from factory.
-diesel in general is absolutely filthy. Fortunately the oil leaks on mine coated the original exhaust so it didnt rust after 40 years in NY/NJ.
Basically, even though these were incredibly popular and common cars, parts dry up for old cars until demand is high enough for someone to churn out one run of a specific part in an african sweatshop. So you need to be a little bit of a hoarder of spare parts to have one as a daily.

Yeah Im gonna have to hard disagree here. The w123 fenders rust around where the BS carter era 5mph bumpers attach, but they did go to great lengths to make sure the rest of the car doesnt rust:

-rockers and all cavities are thoroughly cavity waxed inside, with removable drain plugs available for inspection
-thicker gauge steel than most cars

-loose plastic shields covering exposed areas of lower control arms to protect from rock chips
They're pretty good for steel cars in my experience. Maybe if by "vag" youre comparing to galvanized 944s or aluminum audis, but ive seen plenty of rusty jettas. What special techniques did cheap 90s volkswagens employ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26206125
I have a 300D turbo (I love it: forever car) and will have to disagree with you on a few points.

The turbos do last, mine did 300k before I replaced it and it's just getting into the region of "might want to rebuild it". These are dumb simple garrett T3s, a rebuild kit is $30 and an hour of your time, and you're good for another 300k. You can also put in an aftermarket turbo easily with kits sold by benzforce (I did it, he221w gang).

the injection pumps will wear out eventually on ULSD, so put a little oil of any kind (2 stroke is good) in at every fillup.

Yes, wagon SLS will go. They can be rebuilt cheaply, or SLS deleted with a kit for a few hundred.

vacuum pumps are a very rare failure, it is always the vacuum system leaking somewhere. just fix the leak of block it off.

injector rebuilds are NOT $500, what are you smoking. The forum guy does it for $100 for a set and you can do it yourself for $30/nozzle and a $80 pop tester if you're like that.

ADDITIONAL issues:
climate control nonsense, usually the actuators developing leaks.
the tach will stop working due to bad connection in the tach amp.
the steering box will get loose over time and need tightening

>>26203729
Downshift at the same point when your auto would: when you want more RPMs either because your slowing down or trying to rapidly accelerate. You have to push in the clutch when you come to a stop to keep from stalling the car, but otherwise you use the brakes like you would in an automatic. You also have the option of engine braking by shifting to a lower gear and letting off the gas, which will make the car go slower without wearing the brakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26203494
I think I was 18 or 19. I taught myself with no reference materials or prior knowledge. That might sound impressive, but I was simply terrible at it initially, and would have really benefited from getting someone to show me how to do it.

The first time I came to a stop, I stalled the car. This was not because I "wasn't ready" with the clutch, but rather that I had no idea how the clutch worked, and I didn't realize the engine would stall without the clutch engaged. Internet assholes might call that dumb, but I really just no information about manual transmissions at all, and didn't really know much of anything about cars at the time. In other words, it was extreme ignorance only.

That first failed stop taught me most of what I needed to know, and I was driving around town that same day. It still took be a while to be any good at launching or shifting correctly, but I was had a 1985 Honda Accord with ~165k miles, so it was the perfect car to learn on. I think we bought it for $650.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26204395
>P2096 Code: Post Catalyst Fuel Trim System Too Lean (Bank 1)
could be a vacuum leak. get a propane torch, turn it on without lighting it, and run it up and down all your vacuum lines, hoses, intake, etc with the engine running. if you hit a spot where the engine speeds up, you've found your leak.
i would also clean your MAF sensor (with maf cleaner spray) as a faulty maf can cause unexpected readings at your o2 sensor.
could also be one or more clogged fuel injector, remove them and soak in carb cleaner, you can even apply 12V to the injector to open it as you spray a can of carb cleaner through to test the spray pattern and clean the insides

>When accelerating between 2k-3k rpm, there's a very intense deep humming/vibration from the front
could be a failing CV joint

>>26205607
absolutely, there is nothing wrong with doing that. that's actually one of the things that people who live in very cold climates do to keep their batteries from dying overnight when it's 40 below.
the agm setting likely makes it float charge (~13.5v) once the battery is nearly full rather than having it at full 14.4v the whole time because non flooded batteries require it to not get cooked. I don't think there's any detriment or benefit to using it, there's just no point. just set it to normal and charge and it'll be good to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26206009
That black smoke is from incomplete combustion, because it's running absolutely pig rich. You've gotta figure out what is causing it like leaky fuel injectors, a bad MAF, bad engine coolant temperature sensor making it think it's always cold, unmetered air leaking into the intake (coming in after the MAF), bad upstream O2 sensor, etc. After it sits overnight, does it have a rough start? posts.com: My battery is corroded. Been fine but then it was cold the other day and i had to get jumped. Drove 20 yards and it died. Happened again today. Jump, drive a few feet and it dies. Could it be bad terminals/battery? Or is it definitely the alternator? Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26206819
Could be either, clean the terminals with water and a wire brush and make sure they're tight. If you have a voltmeter, check the voltage at the terminals while it's running, you should see 13-14 volts. If it's 12.6 or under your alternator is either not working or its connection to the battery is bad. If it's not too difficult to get to, check the voltage at it's output stud too to make sure it's not the wire that's bad.

You gotta drill the correct size hole for the size extractor that you use. Depending on the extractor you use, hitting the extractor with a hammer into the hole first will help it bite into the drilled hole.

Pic is from an 05 honda odyssey with~190k miles. It snapped the main bolt holding the Serpentine belt tensioner, shredding the belt and popping off a power steering hose.

The bolt snapped such that the leftover portion was half an inch inside its threaded hole (!). It was eventually extracted from the confined space after struggling with a 90 degree drill and an extractor set, which was used in conjunction with a cordless ratchet.

Otherwise the bracket would need to be removed, but not before cat, alt, ac comp is out of the way.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26208359
Really ENTIRELY depends on the previous owners. Jeeps can be fine over 100k, but take a solid look at them.
I have a "frankenwrangler" in my back yard I experiment with that has 170k miles on it for a 2012, and the thing is totally fine because the prior owner, and now me take pretty good care of it. In fact, nobody would look at the thing and assume it was even close to 100k and I've beat the shit out of it.

Point is, I'd take a well maintained jeep with 100k+ miles over one that someone neglected with 40k. I wouldn't say they are Toyota tier, and can get to over 300k miles with JUST basic maintenance, but they are solid.
Anyone who tries to convince you not to buy an in shape car of any make/model with 100k miles is a literal disingenuous car salesman jew.

>>26207099
>What's a better jack for a home mechanic?

The type of jack OP posted is a floor jack.

Project Farm tested a bunch of these floor jacks which includes Pittsburgh, Daytona, and a variety of the other lower-cost consumer jacks. For perspective, the Snap On floor jack was included. It was also pointed out that it's important the jack wheels be able to rotate freely as the jack needs to reposition itself slightly as the arm moves upwards at an arc.

Floor Jack tested and compared by Project Farm
https://youtu.be/g5_64r2PR7A

Myth Busters used the Arcan floor jack.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26208496
All of the floor jack seals leak pressure a little bit over time. So if you jack something up and then wait, the object may lower itself over time. Project Farm measured this as a loss of weight supported. It's nice that PF picked up on this.

>>26206576
That's the entire issue of shitty public transport infrastructure.
Look at a country like the Netherlands. Everything there is designed to have an alternative to the car.
For cities you've got bicycles, dedicated bike lanes and routes which are often faster than taking a car.
For regional transport you've got buses and a plethora of bus lanes, if you want to go somewhere there's a 90% chance a bus will take you there.
For longer trips you've got trains. Often faster than rush hour traffic, though I will concede the train service isn't the best here.

I also hate public transport and you'd never catch me in either a bus or train, but the ability to use an alternative to the car (With the exception of living in a small town in the northern part of the country) is there, something which a lot of normies use, and something which makes our roads far less congested than American roads despite our insane population density.

Public transport is good because it keeps others off the road so that you can enjoy it in peace.

posts.sub: Did I make a big mistake? 2023 Forester
posts.com:
So my car broke and I spent a good two months looking at used ones. I got really tired of people trying to fuck me over with $20,000 RAV4s with 110k miles, cars in "mint condition" with actual rats living inside of them, etc. I live on top of a mountain, which snows a lot, so I want AWD, and I need an SUV due to the equipment I use in my hobbies.

I make $83,000/yr and am buying a $36k Forester Premium. Paying MSRP with no dealer accessories. I felt while it stretched my budget a little bit, I can more than afford it (I know, that's what poor people say) - and it's better value than dealing with the used car market around here.

Lightly used foresters around here are still going for MSRP. On top of that, I work from home and only drive a couple days a week to go shooting or whatever, so I'll put very few miles on it. I figure in my case, especially given the area I live in I shouldn't get hit too hard by depreciation.. especially since there's people around here who would pay extra to not wait 3 months for an order.

But still, I am paying 15% of my take-home pay on a vehicle. When I asked plebbit, they all told me I was a fucking moron. But with the car payment and insurance factored in, my complete monthly expenses would be $2400.. I'd have $2200 left over. I feel that means I'm not stretching my budget too much.

Thoughts?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26201633
"rice" stands for "race inspired cosmetic enhancements", but really just means anything cosmetic that negative affects a car's performance or tries too hard to make the car look faster/sportier.

I.E. huge ass wings on cars that never see track time, "stance/slammed" stuff, aggressive bodykits with fake vents, etc.

Nothing in the OP pic is really ricey to me, it looks totally fine as it is.

There's a lot of other things that people confuse as being "rice" imo as well, such as vented hoods. They do in fact drop your engine bay temps and thus drop your engine temps a bit. Really not necessary for most cars, mind you, but if you're running a higher power forced induction setup your limiting factor often becomes heat management in which case vented hoods can be the difference between getting 1 more pull and having to end your fun for the evening.

Same with a lot of front bumpers that add functional vents. Sure they aren't necessary for a car that stays on the street and is driven hard once every now and again, but they do in fact provide a tangible benefit past looks.

>>26200766
>the jeep compass trailhawk pro -
For the love of God do NOT buy one. I owned one for two years after having a cheap ass jeep patriot i got at 17 that lasted 11 years. The patriot was ok and it could offroad just enough. BUT the compass "trailhawk" was the biggest peice of shit. The brand new engine burned a quart of oil every 1000 miles, which I only found out because one day driving down the highway my engine shuts off at 60 mph after a "low oil pressure" warning flashed up for 5 seconds. This happened the first time aound 10k miles. And several times after that despite me pouring a fresh quart in once a month. I was then told that the oil consumption rate was normal by the dealership. Aside from that I had shit break on it constantly. Half the parts are from a fiat 500 and it's 4wd is actually just AWD. The final nail in the coffin was when my battery died, but it wasn't actually my battery. It was a very small sub battery that sat on top of my normal battery that INDEPENDENTLY powered the starter motor. So I had a totally fine battery, but because some AA Duracell shit was dead the fucking car wouldn't start. I sold it back to the dealership and bought a 4runner instead and it runs like a dream.

There were a million reasons to fake the moon landing:

-NASA had sunk ungodly amounts of money and to have failed would've made the American public lose all faith in the US Government and most science, not to mention we would've been the laughing stock of the world.

You wouldn't have been crushed by the steering wheel. I'd know, I have - my truck went head-on into a security barrier because I wasn't watching what I was doing. Nissan has bungled its exit from the FIA World Endurance championship as badly as it handled competing in the fiercely competitive sports cars series.

Approximately 40 employees at the Indianapolis-based LMP1 program were notified by e-mail the program had been cancelled Tuesday morning, yet with many of the staffers on vacation for the holidays and away from work e-mail, news of the firing, for some, came from a press release the Japanese brand decided to post in its global newsroom. Those who did turn up for work Tuesday morning were barred access to the building, and senior team officials, who were also caught by surprise, stepped in to call and inform (or confirm) the sudden dismissals for all who worked at the facility.

Nissan's cancelation of the troubled program, just days before Christmas, is the latest chapter in what has been a truly tumultuous journey from concept to race.

Road & Track was present for the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO's debut on Dec. 19, 2014, at Circuit of The Americas, where the radical, front-engine, front-wheel-drive prototype suffered through a troubled introduction that made only modest gains over the next 368 days until the program's termination. https://www.roadandtrack.com/motorsports/news/a27710/nissan-fired-its-lmp1-employees-over-e-mail/

>>26075559
Pretty much..
“Behind the engine and beneath the cockpit is a kinetic energy recovery system using two flywheels developed by Torotrak. The flywheels gain energy from the use of the front brakes then discharges that energy back to the front wheels via a driveshaft running over the top of the combustion engine. The flywheels can also output power to a secondary driveshaft which is connected to a limited-slip differential at the rear of the car which feeds epicyclic gearboxes located in each rear wheel hub, allowing the GT-R to be all-wheel drive if necessary.”

Sound complicated? It should, because it is.

Additionally, while the engine is in front of the driver, it’s also behind the centerline of the front wheels, so it’s more of a front-mid layout. As Bowlby explained in an interview with Racecar Engineering:

“The front tyres on the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO are bigger than the rear tyres – 14 inch wide front vs. 9 inch rear. This is due to the way that mass is distributed in the car. We have moved the weight bias forwards to give us traction for the front-engined, front-wheel drive. We’ve also moved the aero forwards so we’ve moved the capacity of the tyres forward to match the weight distribution. So the aero centre of pressure, the mass centre of gravity and the tyre capacity are all in harmony and that means we have bigger tyres at the front than the rear”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26068883
Mitsubishi Motors completely abandoned RWD cars with the exception of the Starion in the 1980s. This would be one of the many decisions that would bleed the brand over the next few decades.
When the big three of Japan decided to come out with their bespoke luxury brands, Mitsubishi decided there was no need for this despite having basically no clout in the American market, they made fleet and commuter vehicles. This combined with the pathetic 3.0 V6 meant the gussies up Galant known as the Sigma was a failure.
They also gradually fucked up their sports car lineup in the states as well. The DSM cars, Chrysler's FWD sports cars, and the captive import Starion (Chrysler Conquest), occupied slightly varying price levels but were essentially in competition with each other in the same showrooms.
The GTO/3000GT used a twin-turbo version of the 6G72 3.0 V6 in the highest trims. We know now that even this engine struggled to power the AWD system of the over 3500 lb car which wasn't helped by the two turbochargers. What's stranger is that the 6G74 3.5 V6 was dropped in multiple Mitsubishi vehicles, SUVs and sedans, and was able to approach the twin-turbo 6G72 in power in NA form.
During the height of the Fast and Furious tuner hype, Mitsubishi cut corners and made the third generation Eclipse FWD only, but let you have a V6.
The company would spend the 2000s and 2010s producing shitty commuter cars for the states, the market they invested so much into entering through the Chrysler partnership. By the 2010s they were essentially a second class Jap brand like Suzuki and Isuzu.

Clear coat started peeling BEFORE my 03 LX, also made in Canada. The cam seal managed to pop itself out one time and I had oil go everywhere (no idea how it popped out). I think the 8th gen civics just turned out pretty bad, in terms of reliability. You see way more 6th & 7th gens still driving around, so 8th is where they kinda dropped the ball. I had a 2011 Civic Si sedan which was the last year of the 8th generation Civic. I loved it, granted I bought it new and only kept it to 24k miles so I never really experienced any of the issues that come with age but it was a super fun, light car that revved high and felt easy to toss around. it had a mechanical limited slip and the K20 revved to 8200. in 2012 they went to a 2.4L that only revved to like 7k and it made more torque but didn’t feel as fun, and they made it with some new design where the exhaust manifold was integrated into the block so there was no installing a header on it. I think 2009-2011 Si sedan is the one to have.

That's because you're driving a based Accord, doesn't need to rev a lot to do work, but they do sound very unhappy at high rpms, the whole cylinder head is setup to run below 2400 rpm with half the intake valves shut off while cruising in 5th gear.

I've owned 2 ashtray cars.
the car will always have a smell of stale tobacco, mainly during hot days but, you can get most of it out.
I copied the typical "disaster detail" steps you see in yt vids complete with seat removal, center console removal, deep vacuuming, soap, borax, and oxiclean solutions used with an extractor and drill brush on every soft surface.
the only spot I didn't hit super hard was the headliner because it was already weak in some areas.
even after all that it leeches out some stink in the summer heat. charcoal or baking soda cabin filter helps a lot if you run recirculation

it might be worth it if it isn't that bad and you can tolerate the smell.

Great cars but don't expect a true sports car experience. It's ultimately just a nice econobox with an unnecessarily large engine and a manual trans. I had one for a few years and did most of the mods available for them.

Worth it:
>Ktuner
>rear sway bar
>honda factory performance coilover suspension
>cold air intake (Injen is good)
>cat back exhaust (ATLP or Magnaflow)
>wheels and tires

Not worth it:
>J pipe
>stage 1 clutch + lightweight flywheel
>TL Type S differential swap

>>26199989
Thinking about a mid/late 90's 3 series convertible as a summer car. What pros and cons have you experienced?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200042
I have a convertible as well actually, a 1995 325i. I bought the 93 sedan recently as an cheap winter car. Vert is a manual, sedan is autotragic unfortunately. I've had a great experience with both thus far.

Pros:
-Fun to drive
-Fun to work on
-Easy to work on
-the I6 sounds great
-generally reliable (Convertible is at 230k miles and sedan is almost at 247k, engine is strong on both and trans is going to shit on the sedan just because it's a piece of shit 4L30E)
-With stock suspension and a full interior it's still a very comfortable car

Cons:
-Cooling system issues are notorious on E36s, primarily the water pump which uses a plastic impeller, you should get one with a metal impeller as soon as you can
-As these are becoming old you have to start dealing with old car shit like brittle plastics
-They don't rust super bad but they tend to rust around the lifting points when they do, which kind of makes them a pain in the ass and a little sketchy to work under
-There were a lot of them made, but it's going to be a challenge to find a half decent manual example because of their reputations as drift cars and the drift tax, a little easier with convertibles though since they're worse for motorsports
-Parts can sometimes be stupid expensive, especially if you have to get them from overseas which is actually pretty frequent
-For convertibles, stay away from the fully electric tops, they are a bitch
-The interiors on the earlier ones were not BMW's best effort quality wise, a lot of them will either have the door panels jankily screwed in or just no door panels like my convertible
-Window regulators go out a lot (I haven't had any, just a common problem)

These two are the only two BMWs I've ever had but I can recommend ownership based on them. A lot of BMW hate on this board is unwarranted and gay.

What's fascinating for me is the sheer variety of machines during this era of sports car racing. Especially in the early days of BPR and Le Mans before the manufacturers flooded in.
In GT1 you had oddities like
>Aston Martin DB7 LM GT1
>Bugatti EB110SC
>Callaway C7R
>Chevy Corvette C4 ZR-1
>De Tomaso Pantera GT1
>Jaguar XJ220C
>Lotus Esprit GT1
>Nissan 300ZX IMSA
>Renault Spider GT1
>Porsche 911 GT2 Evo

And over in GT2, you have even weirder shit
>Callaway Supernatural Corvette LM
>Ferrari 348 and 355s
>Marcos LM600
>Morgan Plus 8 GTR
>Saleen Mustang GT2

Whoever this is is moron talking out of his ass and doesn't understand that technical regulations don't stay static for decades. Rules change and cars can be eligible for different categories. The McLaren F1 didn't race under the same GT1 regs in 1997 as it did in the years prior. The Toyota GT-One was recategorized as a GTP when GT1 was cancelled. The Viper GTS/R raced as a GT1 in its first year, then rehomologated as a GT2. It'd also race under the IMSA/ACO rules in the GTS category. Then you had the Maserti MC-12 which didn't conform to re-vamped GT1 regs of mid-'00s, but was granted homologation on a waiver anyway because Mosley demanded it.

The main takeaway is that rules change and different racing series can categorize cars as they see fit. GT1 in 1994 was not the same as GT1 in 2005 or GTS in 2001 or GT in 2003. They are all different rule sets.

>>26194439
>>26194907
The desolation in sportscar racing caused by the subsequent collapse of Gr.C (and Gr.B a few years before) led to fans looking at more national-level and single-make series to get their fix. Under these circumstances, Venturi made their own one-make series in 1992 called the Gentleman Driver's Trophy for amateurs which garnered a lot of attention despite being side-events for bigger races. The series used their 400 Trophy racecar and got a lot of response from teams. In charge of the series was Venturi's head of competition services, Stephane Ratel, who is practically the godfather of the modern GT era. In 1993, facing a dwindling prototype field, the ACO allowed production-based cars to fill the rest of the grid for the first time since 1986. The response to their Trophy series and a chance for competing at the LM24, Venturi stepped up to the plate with the 500LM and were represented by no less than 7 cars. They didn't win, but most of the cars actually succeeded in finishing the race.

In 1994, Ratel teamed up with Jurgen Barth and Patrick Peter to make the BPR series which would aim to become the first intercontinental sportscar series since Gr.C folded. Ratel would apply his connections from the Trophy series to get teams to race in BPR giving Venturi a strong presence in a field that would otherwise be a slew of 911s and a single F40 for most of the races. The BPR would continue to grow in 1995 and 1996 with Venturi competing every year until it was taken over by the FIA. During the BPR years Ratel would form the SRO which has been shaping GT racing for almost 30 years.

>>26195544
First, nice Double-Dubs.

Second, something to add was that the performance spike and extremely high running costs of Group C & GTP cars in America in the early 1990s lead to many privateer teams and gentlemen drivers to look elsewhere, which in turn lead to a rise in One-Make series like the Porsche Super Cup and the Ferrari Challenge series. The head if Porsche's competition department at the time? Jurgen Barth.

The biggest mover and shaker in the Ferrari Challenge series when it launched in the 1990s? Patrick Peter.

By early 1993, Stephane Ratel, Barth and Peter started organizing special race weekends where teams in their one-make series that were up for it raced against each other. By Le Mans that year, the BPR GT series was starting to take shape and they just so happened to use the rulebook Le Mans came up with for 1994.

>>26196450
I think Peter's clout back in the '90s was promoting events, especially vintage motorsport. Before BPR, his organization brought back the modern interpretation of the French Tour Auto event in 1992. He would later go on to start the Le Mans Classic in the early-'00s. His connection was useful in filling up the grid as many teams were just amateur drivers that owned or maintained classic racecars.

Barth was basically just famous for his career as a Porsche factory driver having 4 class wins at LM24 with one of those being an outright win in a 936. He was just there to put a famous face on the series and his final class win happened just months before the first BPR race. Essentially the spokesman, he held a lot of celebrity sway over Porsche enthusiasts (and probably why so many teams on the grid were driving Porsches)

Ratel was the main guy running the whole operation. He also used his connections at Venturi to get teams from the Trophy series to sign on to BPR and step up the Trophy cars to one of the new 500LM racecars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26206520
Remember to take breaks, give yourself more time than usual to arrive, and listen to music you like instead of what's on the radio.
And remember that comfort is king. It will slow down exhaustion. People usually think that driving, or riding motorcycles, is easy. But discomfort makes it harder than it should be. And that stress and discomfort tires you out. That circles back to breaks. Stress also tires you out faster.
If you're driving in bad conditions, like winter right now, make sure to evaluate whether you have to drive in them. If you don't, see if you can skip bad conditions. Rent a hotel and stay in for a day if you have to.
If you can avoid it, don't drive late at night. Especially out in the country. Most frightening ride I've done was a 3 AM trip from Hamilton to Barrie at 160kph to be with a friend in a bad time. Not a single cop but I also could have slammed a pothole or hit a few deer that crossed along the way.

>>26202431
It's a better way of measuring vehicle usage. A lot of the hardest wear on vehicles happens at low speeds where you're not accumulating miles quickly but putting relatively high stress on the vehicle. For dirt bikes, going through the woods puts on miles a lot slower than putting down the highway, but you're having more impacts and hard acceleration and braking events. Same for cars in city traffic vs highway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26202421
I think you vastly overestimate the difficulty here on 2 smokers. I try to ride mine every weekend I can in the summer, each ride being about 3 hours depending on how busy I am. That gets me at least 2-3 years before I have to rebuild. I've gone 150+ hours without having to rebuild on a 2 stroke. You can rebuild a 2 stroke in less than 2 hours, it's very simple. Transmission oil changes every ~25 hours which takes 30 minutes. That's about the extent of maintenance on these bikes.

I'm not sure about motocross because those bikes get ridden much harder than us woods-folk, but I'd imagine still at least 100 hours out of a top end.

>>26192124
>Wasn't there a mythbusters about this?
It was about a different topic.

And it is an easy mistake for consumers to think that "gasoline is all the same". It is not. Gasoline does not have an exact set of percentage numbers that it is processed to before being sold to you. The quality and content of crude oil varies greatly even if it is crude from the same well. The refineries get crude from different places and separate and crack and refine it until the gasoline product is good enough to be sold. But the percentages of xylenes, toluene, benzene, butane, pentane etc, can vary from batch to batch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26191920
>What's considered top/low tier?
For top tier brands, Shell V-Power Nitro+ has the most detergent at approx 7X. Costco is the next at 5X. Other brands may have as low as 2.5X as they are at the bottom of the top tier brands. Nevertheless, top tier will always be the better tier because it sets a maximum on how much sulfur and other contaminants can be in the gasoline.

Low-sulfur crude oil (aka Sweet Crude) costs more than regular crude oil that has more sulfur in it. That sulfur requires additional refining to lower it to the point where it qualifies as normal regular gasoline. Top tier regular gasoline requires an even lower sulfur content than specified by the regular gasoline standard.

The issue is "minimum octane rating", as it clearly states on the pump.
My cars needs 93.
But the highest locally is "91".
I get detonation from citgo (7-11) "91" but not other brands of "91".
Agitation lowers octane raring because oxygen is dissolved into the fuel. The farther a gas station is from a refinery, the lower the octane because of the 18 wheeler fuel truck bouncing down the highway.
So to tankers can be filled in sequence at the refinery with 95 octane, but the one that unloads at a gas station 250 mikes away might have 93 octane but the one that delivers to a station 600 miles away has 91 octane by the time he gets there.

On a Tesla? Its not the batteries, its the motor, and not from acceleration. Its from KERS.
Owners have been getting around it on tracks by disabling KERS, and fitting better brakes.

Car makers are going to solve this problem the only way they can just by throwing more stored energy at it.
If you can have 200kWh then achieving 4 or 5 miles a kWh becomes less important and you can spend some more energy on things like pushing radiators through the air to keep the powertrain cool, and of course having more stored energy means not necessarily having to recapture energy in the first place.
200kWh is the magic number because its about how much actual energy output a gas car with an endurance fuel tank can manage, but of course since battery swapping isn't allowed FCEV range extending solutions on cars with 60kWh batteries may ultimately prove more popular for motorsports.

>>26206012
>Most applications don't call for the car to be used in space though.
Its kind of like most common applications for cars don't require them to have 1 MWh of stored energy on board, but there are motorsports that optimize around that niche ability of internal combustion cars.
Hill climbs are some of the oldest types of events, and they've often been a showcase for new automotive technology. Its not surprising that EVs have become dominant in these kind of short form events first even when the top of the hill isn't in the statosphere because of the inherent advantages of electric powertrains outside their ability to operate without oxygen.

Endurance racing is a much harder problem to solve, although that can be for different reasons. For ICE its often a challenge of reliability of mechanical powertrain components. For EVs endurance races are the holy grail for demonstrating the ability to store a lot of energy, and take more energy in pit stops extremely quickly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26206167
>"CIS" became a term to describe NORMAL
It didn't become that, its the Latin word for "This side of", while "trans" is "The other side of". Its why there are places named by the Romans that include those prefixes like Transylvania.
It didn't get that name because Dr Frankfurter lives there. It got its name because it was the "Other side of the Forest".

NASA still routinely use the prefixes in this way. Cis-Lunar being missions on this side of the moon, and Trans-Lunar being missions into space beyond the moon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Your dad probably should have used a clay bar. I've been using this chemical guys wash that's purple, and their blue ceramic wax. I don't even dry the truck really well when I'm done. It's pretty spot free. I'll just towel off the majority of the water and it dries fine.

Whether you use a wash mit or a brush, you want to hose it off before you dip it back in your bucket to get more soap on it. You want to spray as much dirt out of it as it can so you're not just putting swirls in your clear coat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26207556
Hard water won't dull paint, it'll just leave annoying water spots and shit like that.

Like >>26207582 said, take it to a pro shop to get ceramic coated and you won't really have to worry about waxing or anything. I'd ask them about if you can however, since if it were me I'd try to top up the later with a ceramic wax. I personally use ceramic wax and ceramic detailer since they work excellent in combination and last a ridiculously long time, I do my front bumper after every wash and it makes the bugs slide right off with just a little water when I go to rewash my car again later.

26 DEC 2022

Police are solving only 1% of catalytic converter thefts, data suggests

Tens of thousands of catalytic converter thefts are going unsolved, with only 1% of cases resulting in someone being charged, figures obtained by the Liberal Democrats suggest.

Data from 20 police forces in England and Wales for 2017-2021 indicate a suspect was charged in only 548 cases.

Catalytic converters fitted in car exhaust systems reduce their emission of toxic gases and pollutants.

Thieves are attracted by the valuable metals the devices contain.

Police say converters can often be removed in under a minute, and are most frequently stolen in car parks, before being sold to scrapyards, online or shipped out of the country.

Hybrid vehicles are most commonly targeted as their metals are more valuable, but any vehicle can be at risk of catalytic converter theft.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200890

The Home Office says it has national programmes to target metal theft, including catalytic converters.

The police figures were disclosed in response to a Freedom of Information request.

In the 20 police areas where full information was provided, a total of 50,223 thefts of catalytic converters were reported in the five-year period.

Full figures from some of the biggest forces - including West Midlands Police and Greater Manchester Police - were not available.

In the 20 force areas surveyed, the number of thefts surged from 742 reported in 2017 to 19,451 in 2020, before falling in 2021 - the first full year of the Covid pandemic - to 15,780.

By far the highest number of thefts from 2017-2021 - 36,586 - occurred in London. Just 544 were solved.

In Hertfordshire, in 2020, 915 cases were recorded; in South Yorkshire, the figure was 669. No one was charged in either police area in that year.

The Liberal Democrats have called for more to be done to crack down on the problem, including more visible community policing to deter thieves.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26200905

Crime prevention

A Home Office spokesperson said: "We recognise the impact that theft can have on victims and we want offenders charged and brought to justice in the courts.

"Since the National Infrastructure Crime Reduction Partnership was set up in 2020, there has been significant success in tackling metal theft through co-ordinated national action against scrap metal dealers - including a marked increase in enforcement action from police and partner agencies."

During two weeks of national action to tackle catalytic converter and other metal theft, 64 arrests were made and more than 1,000 converters and other stolen items were recovered, the spokesperson added.

Police say that although catalytic converter thefts are increasing, there are steps that can be taken to protect a vehicle.

They suggest asking a car dealer for advice on approved locks or guards, registering the converter and marking it with a forensic marker.

Alternatively, they say, try to make sure the vehicle is parked in a garage overnight, or in a secure compound if it is a commercial vehicle.

Otherwise, police add, park in an area that is well-lit and overlooked, and try to park so the converter can not be easily reached by potential thieves. Vehicles that sit high above the road are said to be particularly vulnerable.

Older fuel lines (pre 2001) can have problems with ethanol and some alloys could experience corrosion too. Everything afterwards should be fine, jap cars were already fine after 1990 if I remember correctly.
Ethanol has a enthalpy of vaporization that is 3 times higher than regular gas and therefore takes heat away from your engine.
Problem is like in my case where I didn’t make any ECM adjustments is that the engine runs lean since the energy density of ethanol is smaller and therefore combustion temperatures are higher, which makes me fear that the cat could suffer.

Hydro has even worse energy density (volumetric)

>>26204842
>>26204842
>For instance, refusing a breathalyzer can get you arrested and your blood drawn depending on the state and county of course.

that's what I did. I had always heard people say "don't blow" in order to boost your chances with a DUI. In reality it doesn't matter. I was arrested and had my blood drawn. Took them long to test the blood which extended my probation/punishment. Court date wasn't til a year after I got pulled over. Judge wanted to throw me in jail for a weekend, but I got off with 2 years probation, no in car breathalyzer or loss of license (had order of stay placed upon the revocation of my license).

Overall, my lawyer said that where I fucked up was that I refused the breathalyzer, but I still did the other sobriety tests. They asked me to say the alphabet backwards starting with W and ending with F and I failed that. They also asked me to walk in a perfectly straight line on the side of the road and failed that (along with standing on one leg, touching finger to nose, etc). All that was on the cop's dashcam.

My lawyer said I would've been better off just doing the breathalyzer because it shows I am cooperative and thus cops will go easier on you, whereas if you refuse anything they see you as "a rebel" and try to fuck you more to make you understand the long dick of the law.

Lawyer did say if possible it might've turned out better if I had also refused field sobriety tests in addition to breathalyzer. They still would've taken my blood, but it could have been argued that the amount of time I sat waiting for my blood to be drawn increased my BAC to higher than it was when I was pulled over, and since I was close to home, maybe I would've got off, though he said that was unlikely.

States that mandate the blood draw are retarded. NYer here and I refused to blow, got arrested, license was suspended, then I got a conditional license for work and school while waiting for a dmv court date, criminal case was settled for a driving infraction and a 1 year ACD. The cop never came to dmv court and the karen judge was so mad at me that she bearded me on tape before dismissing the dmv case. I got my license fully back and went on to finish grad school and get my certification in my field. Lawyer told me the smartest thing I did was not blow because giving them an objective number is always worse than leaving it up the interpretation whether I was drunk or just tired. Most jury members will try the field sobriety test at home and fail it. Who the hell knows the alphabet backwards? Or how can you prove someone is drunk because they were too fast in estimating 15 seconds? They could be nervous for example.

Never drive drunk, but when you do NEVER BLOW.

Depends on the state. In most, not all, states, any refusal of a sample of blood, breath, or urine is an automatic license suspension and being placed under arrest for suspicion of DUI/OVI. Then you stay until you're released to another party. You'll be cited for DUI/OVI, anyway and have to fight it in court. Then the best you can hope for is that the arresting officer/trooper doesn't fucking show up and the case gets dropped. That's only about 10% of the time though. When it comes down to your word against an officer or trooper and prosecuting attorney, you're pretty much going to have to fight like hell. They'll definitely pull the video and any transcripts to use against you.

>TL;DR LAWYER THE FUCK UP NO MATTER WHAT THE COST

So assuming timing can stay the same (stock ECU controlled), and I can determine AFR. Stock injectors are 251cc, that's good for a max of 500ish hp. Forums say the stock ECU is good for about 7psi, more or less .5 bar. A 50% increase in volume, so the stock ECU will push about 360ish HP of fuel. That means I'm only port injecting (basically a carb/TBI, really) another 140hp of fuel at 14psi, so two 500cc injectors should work. Have it referenced to boost and throttle position via Arduino, and run the injectors out of phase to increase spray continuity. I want to do this under 2 grand and have most of the equipment.

>fire truck up for an oil change
>hoping to get to drive it this winter as ive been neglecting it for a few years now
>fire it up
>idles at 2k
>shut it off
>unplug idle air motor
>500rpm idle to limp it around
>drive it down the street
>it won't shift or shifts nonsensically
>read about symptoms
>talk to frens
>theyre saying that either it's a vaccum leak or tps
>read about voltage range for tps
>it's like 0.5 to 5v
>check it with throttle shut
>3v
>order a new tps
>install it
>truck run happy and shifts now
happy truck

posts.com:
The timing chain on my suzuki got loose, skipped a few teeth and ran super rough for a couple days and then I spun a bearing on one of my con rods :(

I tried to get the engine out to work on it, but I needed to undo the entire front end and drop the engine out from underneath the car. I don't have a lift to do that so I did everything I side the engine bay which sucked.

Changed the whole timing chain assembly, and swapped all the con rod bearings. The rod journal on the crankshaft of the spun bearing is gouged to shit. I polished as best I could with sandpaper, replaced the bearing and put everything back together. Finished the job yesterday. Surprisingly the car runs super smooth now. Better than before lol

I don't trust the car or my bogan fix so I think I will sell it and buy a Toyota

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In middle school and high school dad taught me basics of wrenching. He bought me a shit box 04 Miata that had been roached by the previous owner. Spent middle school fixing stuff on it, highschool making it look passable. We spent a lot of time together on that car and brought it back from being a near complete write off to a decent all around car. We were both proud. In my second year of college my father was killed by a drunk driver while on his motorcycle. I cried by myself when I got the news in my dorm. Didn't cry again after that. Comforting mom and sis back home, nothing. Went to the funeral, nothing. It's like nothing was real so I couldn't relate to any of it, I couldn't feel sad about it. A few years later my Miata was totaled when I hydroplaned on the freeway and spun it into a guardrail. Mechanical problems I can sort if given enough time. Electrical are tedious but also manageable. But when the engines been almost torn out, and the front end of the car disintegrated across the roadway? I can't fix that extent of damage. I'm glad I walked away alive at the speed I was going, a couple broken ribs and collarbone. But I cried for weeks on and off realizing I lost that car. Realizing the thing we worked on together was gone and it's my fault. I still feel incredible shame years after later and probably will my whole life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200378
I don't own cars I don't love. I currently own a 2012 Challenger R/T that I got new as well as a 1989 Ramcharger on a chopped 1992 W250 chassis with a 6BT. Both are dream cars I will never let go of. I'll modify and enjoy them both for the rest of my life, no matter the cost. Only car in my immediate future is a 1997 F-150 my dad taught me to drive in. Has a broken crank and it's been sitting in a field for years. Gonna rescue and restore it because it is a physical representation of my childhood. I'll give it back to my dad when I'm done, but it'll come back to me.

Otherwise, I've owned two other Ramchargers and a D250. First Ramcharger was destroyed by a tornado. Second I sold to a fellow Mopar enthusiast when I got my third one. The D250 I gave to a friend who helped me rescue it from a field so he could sell it and finance his family moving across the country.

I regret leaving the first Ramcharger to its fate, but the other two I let go of for good reasons, so I don't hurt too bad over them. I miss my second Ramcharger, though, because it was a healthy and good condition truck that could have been easily restored into a daily. My current one is a mammoth off road rig and farm truck. It'll never be nice and I probably won't ever own a fourth one that could be cleaned up and used around town.
